trans-unit.source: target_fps: How many captures per second to aim for. The effective capture rate will go under if the system can't keep up but it will never go over this target. It is recommended to set this to a reasonable value for your use case in order not to waste system resources. Default is set to 60.

trans-unit.source: D3DShot is a pure Python implementation of the Windows Desktop Duplication API. It leverages DXGI and Direct3D system libraries to enable extremely fast and robust screen capture functionality for your Python scripts and applications on Windows.
trans-unit.target: D3DShot is a pure Python implementation of the Windows Desktop Duplication API. It leverages DXGI and Direct3D system libraries to enable extremely fast and robust screen capture functionality for your Python scripts and applications on Windows.

trans-unit.source: D3DShot is however quite flexible! As your environment meets certain optional sets of requirements, more options become available.
trans-unit.target: D3DShot is however quite flexible! As your environment meets certain optional sets of requirements, more options become available.

trans-unit.source: D3DShot leverages DLLs that are already available on your system so the dependencies are very light. Namely:
trans-unit.target: D3DShot leverages DLLs that are already available on your system so the dependencies are very light. Namely:

trans-unit.source: Returns: A boolean indicating whether or not the capture thread was started
trans-unit.target: Returns: A boolean indicating whether or not the capture thread was started

trans-unit.source: Returns: A frame with a format that matches the capture output you selected when creating your D3DShot object
trans-unit.target: Returns: A frame with a format that matches the capture output you selected when creating your D3DShot object

trans-unit.source: Returns: A list of frames with a format that matches the capture output you selected when creating your D3DShot object
trans-unit.target: Returns: A list of frames with a format that matches the capture output you selected when creating your D3DShot object

trans-unit.source: Returns: A screenshot with a format that matches the capture output you selected when creating your D3DShot object
trans-unit.target: Returns: A screenshot with a format that matches the capture output you selected when creating your D3DShot object

trans-unit.source: Returns: A single array stacked on the specified dimension with a format that matches the capture output you selected when creating your D3DShot object. If the capture output is not stackable, returns a list of frames.
trans-unit.target: Returns: A single array stacked on the specified dimension with a format that matches the capture output you selected when creating your D3DShot object. If the capture output is not stackable, returns a list of frames.

trans-unit.source: Returns: A string representing the full path to the saved image file
trans-unit.target: Returns: A string representing the full path to the saved image file

trans-unit.source: Returns: None
trans-unit.target: Returns: None

trans-unit.source: As always, remember that benchmarks are inherently flawed and highly depend on your individual hardware configuration and other circumstances. Use the numbers below as a relative indication of what to expect from D3DShot, not as some sort of absolute truth.
trans-unit.target: As always, remember that benchmarks are inherently flawed and highly depend on your individual hardware configuration and other circumstances. Use the numbers below as a relative indication of what to expect from D3DShot, not as some sort of absolute truth.

trans-unit.source: Be mindful of RAM usage with larger values; You will be dealing with uncompressed images which use up to 100 MB each depending on the resolution.
trans-unit.target: Be mindful of RAM usage with larger values; You will be dealing with uncompressed images which use up to 100 MB each depending on the resolution.

trans-unit.source: Don't tell anyone but the reason it can compete with NumPy in the first place is only because... it is generated from a NumPy array built from the method above! If you sniff around the code, you will indeed find torch.from_numpy() scattered around. This pretty much matches the speed of the "numpy" capture output 1:1, except when dealing with a rotated display. Display rotation is handled by np.rot90() calls which yields negative strides on that array. Negative strides are understood and perform well under NumPy but are still unsupported in PyTorch at the time of writing. To address this, an additional copy operation is needed to bring it back to a contiguous array which imposes a performance penalty.
trans-unit.target: Don't tell anyone but the reason it can compete with NumPy in the first place is only because... it is generated from a NumPy array built from the method above! If you sniff around the code, you will indeed find torch.from_numpy() scattered around. This pretty much matches the speed of the "numpy" capture output 1:1, except when dealing with a rotated display. Display rotation is handled by np.rot90() calls which yields negative strides on that array. Negative strides are understood and perform well under NumPy but are still unsupported in PyTorch at the time of writing. To address this, an additional copy operation is needed to bring it back to a contiguous array which imposes a performance penalty.

trans-unit.source: How is the "numpy" capture output performance that good?
trans-unit.target: How is the "numpy" capture output performance that good?

trans-unit.source: If you are capturing a scaled display, the region will be computed against the full, non-scaled resolution.
trans-unit.target: If you are capturing a scaled display, the region will be computed against the full, non-scaled resolution.

trans-unit.source: If you go through the source code, you will notice that the region cropping happens after a full display capture. That might seem sub-optimal but testing has revealed that copying a region of the GPU D3D11Texture2D to the destination CPU D3D11Texture2D using CopySubresourceRegion is only faster when the region is very small. In fact, it doesn't take long for larger regions to actually start becoming slower than the full display capture using this method. To make things worse, it adds a lot of complexity by having the surface pitch not match the buffer size and treating rotated displays differently. It was therefore decided that it made more sense to stick to CopyResource in all cases and crop after the fact.
trans-unit.target: If you go through the source code, you will notice that the region cropping happens after a full display capture. That might seem sub-optimal but testing has revealed that copying a region of the GPU D3D11Texture2D to the destination CPU D3D11Texture2D using CopySubresourceRegion is only faster when the region is very small. In fact, it doesn't take long for larger regions to actually start becoming slower than the full display capture using this method. To make things worse, it adds a lot of complexity by having the surface pitch not match the buffer size and treating rotated displays differently. It was therefore decided that it made more sense to stick to CopyResource in all cases and crop after the fact.

trans-unit.target: It's a way lighter / simpler dependency for a library compared to NumPy or PyTorch

trans-unit.source: Measuring the exact performance of the Windows Desktop Duplication API proves to be a little complicated because it will only return new texture data if the contents of the screen has changed. This is optimal for performance but it makes it difficult to express in terms of frames per second, the measurement people tend to expect for benchmarks. Ultimately the solution ended up being to run a high FPS video game on the display to capture to make sure the screen contents is different at all times while benchmarking.
trans-unit.target: Measuring the exact performance of the Windows Desktop Duplication API proves to be a little complicated because it will only return new texture data if the contents of the screen has changed. This is optimal for performance but it makes it difficult to express in terms of frames per second, the measurement people tend to expect for benchmarks. Ultimately the solution ended up being to run a high FPS video game on the display to capture to make sure the screen contents is different at all times while benchmarking.

trans-unit.source: NumPy arrays have a ctypes interface that can give you their raw memory address (X.ctypes.data). If you have the memory address and size of another byte buffer, which is what we end up with by processing what returns from the Desktop Duplication API, you can use ctypes.memmove to copy that byte buffer directly to the NumPy structure, effectively bypassing as much Python as possible.
trans-unit.target: NumPy arrays have a ctypes interface that can give you their raw memory address ( X.ctypes.data ). If you have the memory address and size of another byte buffer, which is what we end up with by processing what returns from the Desktop Duplication API, you can use ctypes.memmove to copy that byte buffer directly to the NumPy structure, effectively bypassing as much Python as possible.

trans-unit.source: Once you have a D3DShot instance in scope, we can start doing stuff with it!
trans-unit.target: Once you have a D3DShot instance in scope, we can start doing stuff with it!

trans-unit.source: Only has an effect on NumPy and PyTorch capture outputs.
trans-unit.target: Only has an effect on NumPy and PyTorch capture outputs.

trans-unit.source: PIL Image objects tend to be familiar to Python users
trans-unit.target: PIL Image objects tend to be familiar to Python users

trans-unit.source: PIL has no ctypes interface like NumPy so a bytearray needs to be read into Python first and then fed to PIL.Image.frombytes(). This is still fast in Python terms, but it just cannot match the speed of the low-level NumPy method.
trans-unit.target: PIL has no ctypes interface like NumPy so a bytearray needs to be read into Python first and then fed to PIL.Image.frombytes() . This is still fast in Python terms, but it just cannot match the speed of the low-level NumPy method.

trans-unit.source: The absolute fastest capture outputs appear to be "numpy" and unrotated "pytorch"; all averaging around 58 FPS. In Python land, this is FAST!
trans-unit.target: The absolute fastest capture outputs appear to be "numpy" and unrotated "pytorch"; all averaging around 58 FPS. In Python land, this is FAST!

trans-unit.source: The buffer is used by the following methods:
trans-unit.target: The buffer is used by the following methods:

trans-unit.source: The data of the Direct3D textures made accessible by the Desktop Duplication API is formatted as bytes. To represent this data as normalized floats instead, a type cast and element-wise division needs to be performed on the array holding those bytes. This imposes a major performance penalty. Interestingly, you can see this performance penalty mitigated on GPU PyTorch tensors since the element-wise division can be massively parallelized on the device.
trans-unit.target: The data of the Direct3D textures made accessible by the Desktop Duplication API is formatted as bytes. To represent this data as normalized floats instead, a type cast and element-wise division needs to be performed on the array holding those bytes. This imposes a major performance penalty. Interestingly, you can see this performance penalty mitigated on GPU PyTorch tensors since the element-wise division can be massively parallelized on the device.

trans-unit.source: The desired Capture Output is defined when creating a D3DShot instance. It defines the type of all captured images. By default, all captures will return PIL.Image objects. This is a good option if you mostly intend to take screenshots.
trans-unit.target: The desired Capture Output is defined when creating a D3DShot instance. It defines the type of all captured images. By default, all captures will return PIL.Image objects. This is a good option if you mostly intend to take screenshots.

trans-unit.source: The files will be named according to this convention: <frame buffer index>.png
trans-unit.target: The files will be named according to this convention: <frame buffer index>.png

trans-unit.source: The frame buffer can be accessed directly with d.frame_buffer but the usage of the utility methods instead is recommended.
trans-unit.target: The frame buffer can be accessed directly with d.frame_buffer but the usage of the utility methods instead is recommended.

trans-unit.source: These dependencies will automatically be installed alongside D3DShot; No need to worry about them!
trans-unit.target: These dependencies will automatically be installed alongside D3DShot; No need to worry about them!

trans-unit.source: This low-level operation is extremely fast, leaving everything else that would normally compete with NumPy in the dust.

trans-unit.source: This operation is threaded and non-blocking. It will keep running until d.stop() is called.
trans-unit.target: This operation is threaded and non-blocking. It will keep running until d.stop() is called.

trans-unit.source: This operation is threaded and non-blocking. It will keep running until d.stop() is called. Captures are pushed to the frame buffer.
trans-unit.target: This operation is threaded and non-blocking. It will keep running until d.stop() is called. Captures are pushed to the frame buffer.

trans-unit.source: Usage
trans-unit.target: Ïö©Î≤ï

trans-unit.source: When you create a D3DShot instance, a frame buffer is also initialized. It is meant as a thread-safe, first-in, first-out way to hold a certain quantity of captures and is implemented as a collections.deque.
trans-unit.target: When you create a D3DShot instance, a frame buffer is also initialized. It is meant as a thread-safe, first-in, first-out way to hold a certain quantity of captures and is implemented as a collections.deque .

trans-unit.source: When you create a D3DShot instance, your available displays will automatically be detected along with all their relevant properties.
trans-unit.target: When you create a D3DShot instance, your available displays will automatically be detected along with all their relevant properties.

trans-unit.source: Windows 8.1+ (64-bit)
trans-unit.target: Windows 8.1+ (64-bit)

trans-unit.source: Windows has a quirk when using Desktop Duplication on hybrid-GPU systems. Please see the wiki article before attempting to use D3DShot on your system.
trans-unit.target: Windows has a quirk when using Desktop Duplication on hybrid-GPU systems. Please see the wiki article before attempting to use D3DShot on your system.

trans-unit.source: Windows only allows 1 instance of Desktop Duplication per process. To make sure we fall in line with that limitation to avoid issues, the D3DShot class acts as a singleton. Any subsequent calls to d3dshot.create() will always return the existing instance.
trans-unit.target: Windows only allows 1 instance of Desktop Duplication per process. To make sure we fall in line with that limitation to avoid issues, the D3DShot class acts as a singleton. Any subsequent calls to d3dshot.create() will always return the existing instance.

trans-unit.source: Your primary display is selected by default but if you have a multi-monitor setup, you can select another entry in d.displays
trans-unit.target: Your primary display is selected by default but if you have a multi-monitor setup, you can select another entry in d.displays
